ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about many different, relevant studies in neuroscience across an array of topics.
Learned about neural mechanisms behind social interactions through reading papers on studies of different organisms
I learned so much about reading and understanding scientific research papers

- Gained a lot of practice in reading neuroscience papers and discussing figures 
- Read many of the most influential papers and findings in the field of social neuroscience
I learned a lot about the research methods neuroscientists use to engage with challenging questions about cognition and social interaction.

We learned a lot about how to interpret the experimental design of research submitted for our field by peer review. We learned a lot about the various techniques involved in exploring various hypothesis related to behavioral neurosciences.
I learned how to read challenging scientific articles, how to think critically, and how to go deeper into a neuroscience topic of my choice.

By taking this course, I learned about the neural mechanisms that underlay different aspects of social interaction. Importantly, I learned about key experimental techniques (fMRI, optogenetics, and so on) that are used to operationalize and study the hypotheses that were tested in the papers we read.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths was the level of depth that was pushed by the material, but more discussion could be useful amongst students!

strengths - heavy discussion course 
weakness - none great seminar class for neuro major
I think it would be great to include more juman subject studied

Strengths: I liked the steady workload (no surprises and very manageable) and Dr. Chang is a great, easygoing professor who really helps with understanding the material, which is also interesting. this was a good class to be in a seminar format 

Weaknesses: sometimes that format of the class became repetitive (always spending it in discussion around 2 papers) so maybe it could have helped to occasionally change up how we discussed the papers
Strengths: learn a lot about social neuroscience in a short period of time. Weakness: if you dont already have a basis in neuroscience and brain regions you will not get much out of the class.

strengths: I've taken other psychology senior seminars, and one thing about this class was that it really forced you read the papers because the entire class discussion was on the papers. And through reading the assigned papers, I began to understand the experimental techniques employed 

weakness: I wish there was more time to talk as classmates during the discussion or some way to encourage it. I think the issue was in part was that the class was in early in the morning and so people didn't really want tot talk. I would also would have preferred the option to write a 10 page paper ver a 20 page paper if I wasn't planning on using this class t complete the senior class. I had taken a class where students could do 10 over 20 pages if it wasn't for the thesis.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are at all interested in learning about many different and important experiments in the world of neuroscience, take this course!
yes if genuinely interested in the social aspects of neuroscience and if you love open discussion and reading papers
Yes, I really enjoyed it!
Yes, I'd recommend it for the professor and for the material -- I also think that neuroscience majors should try to take a seminar in neuroscience before they graduate!

If you are interested in reading scientific papers and have a strong grasp on brain regions this class would be very interesting. The workload isnt too drastic and the articles you read are very current
I would highly recommend taking this course. I came away being able to thoroughly understand what the techniques being employed in these key studies were.
